resources.string: This digital version of the pool lifeguard manual acts as a supplement to the Android application. It is not designed to replace the existing hard copy of the Pool Lifeguard Manual. It is meant to be used as a quick reference by examiners and participants during the pool lifeguard examination. For a more comprehensive understanding and greater detail, consult the full Pool Lifeguard Manual, available from Irish Water Safety.
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Praesent odio diam, maximus in risus vel, aliquet ultricies tortor. Cras placerat ipsum sit amet urna sollicitudin, a mollis leo faucibus.

Inverted breast stroke - The upper part of the leg is kept in line with the body. As the knees open slightly the legs are lowered and the feet are "cocked". The legs are then swept sideways and together in a swirling or circular movement with the insides of the lower legs pressing against the resistance of the water.

The ability to reverse from the prone swimming position, in order to move quickly out of a subject\'s reach or to assume a "ready" position prior to affecting a rescue is essential to the safety of the rescuer.

The threatened swimmer tries to avoid the subject\'s grasp by tucking in his chin. At the same time he pushes his attacker with both hands at hip, waist, shoulders or chest. A vigorous extension of the arms upwards forces the subject to the surface, as the swimmer submerges to make his escape underwater. All actions should be carried out speedily and aggressively.

When grasped around the head and neck from the front the rescuer should immediately take a quick breath, tuck in his chin, and submerge himself and the subject. By pushing vigorously upwards with his hands on the subject\'s hips, ribs or armpits he should loosen the grasp sufficiently to duck free. Speed is essential to prevent the subject locking his legs around the rescuer.

An alternative technique is for the rescuer to reach over the subject\'s arm, place their hand on opposite side of subject\'s face, place thumb and heel of hand place under jawbone and their hand spread across the victim\'s face, little finger pressed against the side of the nose. The rescuer takes a grip with his other hand on the subject\'s arm, just above the elbow. By pushing upwards on the arm and away on the face the rescuer can break the grip and turn the subject. The grip on the arm is held while the other hand is withdrawn from the face and used to effect the "level".

The rescuer is gripped around the arms and body. He should in turn grasp the subject on both sides of the body at any position he can reach. The armpits or base of the ribs are preferred positions. Tucking in his chin and thrusting his elbows away from his side the rescuer forcefully pushes the subject away and upwards. The rescuer is forced below the surface and can back away under water.

For an effective and speedy rescue, the rescuer must be able to level the subject into the horizontal position on the back. This position may be achieved quickly as the carry or tow gets under way. In the case of a heavy subject it may be necessary for the rescuer to assist in the levelling by using a hand placed in the centre of the back. The level is then maintained by the speed of the carry and by the support of the rescuer\'s lower body underneath the subject. The subject\'s head is levered firmly backwards while the rescuer strokes vigorously with legs and free arm.

Chest carry - The subject\'s shoulder should fit snugly into the rescuer\'s armpit with his head on the rescuer\'s shoulder. When changing from level to cross-chest carry the rescuer brings the swimming arm over the shoulder of the subject, securing a grip towars the far armpit with the forearm across the chest and the elbow held firmly down.

Head carry - From the levelling position, the rescuer takes a firm hold of the subject\'s head (palms of the hands on the ears, fingers extended along the jaws and thumbs on the temples) and tows to safety. The arm are held straight with the wrists depressed, except when it is necessary to raise the subject\'s head, where they are bent to form a right angle at the elbows.

Hair carry - From the "level" position, the rescuer brings the stroking hand to the back of the subject\'s head, with fingers partially spread, and slides them forward to grasp the hair. The wrist is depressed and with the arm straight, the rescuer tows the subject to safety, checking constantly that the subject\'s face is above water. Either arm can be used to "level". The other arm us used to carry while always maintaining contact during change over.

As soon as the rescuer feels the arms encircling his head he should do two things automatically i.e. tuck his chin and get a good breath of air. He should then submerge with the subject. This may force the subject to release his grip. However, if it is necessary to break the grasp, the rescuer should seize the wrist of the subject\'s lower arm with his opposite hand and with the other hand get a forking grip just above the elbow of the same arm, thumb on the inside. By twisting the subject\'s hand outwards and pushing up the elbow with the other hand he can then duck under the elbow that he had forced up to position himself behind the subject. The grip on the wrist should be held until the other hand is moved from the elbow to the chin to take a "level".

An alternative technique is for the rescuer to bring his hands to the underside of the victim\'s arms just above the elbows. Keeping the chin tucked in and the shoulders lifted the rescuer pushes upwards forcefully. While twisting the head and shoulders he pushes the subject back and away. As the subject releases the grip the rescuer swims up and out of reach.
Where the victim is facedown, a head clamp technique can be used to immobilize the head and neck while rotating the victim into a face-up position on the surface of the water.
From a position alongside the victim, the rescuer grasps each arm between shoulder and elbow and gently extends the arms forward on each side of the victim\'s head.
With arms pressed firmly alongside the victim\'s head, a splint or clamp is provided to immobalize the head and neck.

A slow headfirst directed glide will move the victim towards a horizontal position from which the body can more easily be rotated into a face-up position. The body is now rotated by pressing the victim\'s nearest arm underneath the water while, at the same time drawing the other arm across the surface until the body rests on the crook of the rescuer\'s arm.

Immobilisation is maintained in that position while the rescuer checks breathing. Rescue breathing may be applied, if necessary, by using the chest and one arm to maintain the head clamp. N.B. This technique to immobilize the head and neck can be used in deep or shallow water.

Move close to the victim\'s side, at shoulder depth, so that the victim\'s body is against your chest. You may have to move the arm nearest to you so that the victim\'s shoulder and arm are in position against your chest. Place one forearm along the sternum with the fingers grasping the victim\'s chin (thumb to one side of the chin, fingers to the other side) and the other forearm along the victim\'s spine with the hand supporting the base of the skull.

Squeeze both forearms together to create a vice, which clamps the victim\'s chest and back. The hand and fingers are tightened to restrict movement of the head to secure immobilisation. Glide the victim forward to a horiztonal position and commence rescue breathing, if necessary.

N.B. If the victim is face-down, the body must be rotated to a face-up position. Using the same rescue method, gently slide under the victim, rotating the body to a face-up position as you surface at the other side of the victim, while retaining your hands and forearms clamp grip.
